comments:
CHEM 053 is a general laboratory course that covers the aspects of qualitative
and quantitative analysis, the determination of chemical and physical properties, and
chemical synthesis.
The majority of students found the lectures “helpful” and “beneficial to attend.”
Students also generally liked the labs, saying that they were “pretty straightforward” and
“usually worked well.”
Students virtually unanimously found Professor Maeyer to be highly “engaging”
and “approachable.” One student wrote that she was “always trying her best to improve
both the course and her methods of teaching it.”
Most students would not recommend CHEM 053 to a non-major; however, the
course comes highly recommended for those taking the corresponding chemistry course,
as most found that it gives students a better understanding of the material. Students
reported that the lab practical was very difficult and included somewhat unfair questions.
Many students also found grading to be somewhat subjective.

This is a general chemistry laboratory course covering aspects of qualitative and
quantitative analysis, determination of chemical and physical properties, and chemical
synthesis.
Some students found the overall course to be very interesting and offer an
educational way to apply chemistry concepts learned in lecture and translate them over
into real lab work. Other students said the course was very disorganized. Many students
did not believe the labs were very interesting.
Professor Maeyer was said to a very lively professor. Students found the labs to
be very uninteresting. They also found the written exams to be fairly difficult. One
student said Professor Maeyer “is extraordinarily accessible and energetic. She
stimulates interest and enthusiasm where it could easily be lacking.”
Students said that the course required a lot of preparation and work. This course
has a lab fee of $150.

CHEM053 is a general laboratory course covering aspects of qualitative and
quantitative analysis, determination of chemical and physical properties, and chemical
synthesis.
Students overall got what they expected from the course. Because it is an
introductory laboratory class, many of the experiments were very straightforward and
some students felt they did not learn a great deal from doing them. However, there were a
few who felt that the lab did help them “visualize some of the topics” covered in
CHEM101.
Professor Maeyer received mostly mixed reviews. Most students felt that lectures
were interesting and helpful, but some others thought they were somewhat unnecessary.
Some students thought Professor Maeyer was “wonderful” and a “great speaker,” while
others thought she could at times be “disorganized.”
Because it was an introductory laboratory course, most students taking it were
underclassmen. Students, in general, felt that the exams were very difficult with averages
around 60%. Since it is a standard introductory laboratory class, it is recommended for
engineers and pre-health students, and most science majors.
